data.title: Last King Of The Two Sicilies

data.text:
LYING side by side in a plain closed

railway wagon, the bodies of King

Francis II, the last sovereign of the

Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, and his

Queen, Maria Sophia of Wittelsbach,

whose brief reign in Naples was cut

short by the final unification of Italy

under the House of Savoy, reached

Rome recently and were carried to the

church of San Spirito de'Napoletani

(writes the Rome correspondent of the

"Times Weekly"). Only a few Neapoli-

tan noblemen escorted the coffins.

The bodies rested on a, catafalque in

the crypt of the church, where they

were interred early in January in two

tombs which were prepared in the crypt

near that of their only child, the in-

fant Princesa Marie Cristina Pia. The

two exiles were thus reunited with the

"sole consolation" of their first years

of exile, and are now surrounded by

many of the illustrious nobles of their

Court who attended them from Gaeta to

Rome, there to die between 1862 and

1869 and receive burial in the church

which is above all others dear to the

Neapolitans, to whom it was presented

by the Pope in 1572.

The King, who died in 1894 while on

a visit to Austria, was buried at Arco,

then in Austrian territory, and now in

the Italian Trentino, and his body has

been lying for many years in the fam-

ily tomb of the Counts Consolati at

Trent. Queen Maria Sophia died in

1925 at Munich, where she was buried.

The final decision to bring their re-

mains to Italy is believed to have been

made easier by the recent marriage of

the Duke of Ancona, a cousin of the

King of Italy, and Princess Lucia,

daughter of the Duke of Calabria, the

present head of that branch of the

House of Bourbon which used to reign

in Naples, as it ended the estrangement

between tha two dynasties.
